snippet: It started when the Ohio Election Commission received a complaint against a mechanical engineer who, on Twitter, asked voters to stop a streetcar project.
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column on case in which mechanical engineer Mark W Miller, who had urged voters on Twitter to stop a Cincinnati streetcar project during November 2011 election, is suing the Ohio Election Commission after receiving complaint under an Ohio law that forbids false statements in political campaigns; observes that courts are split about whether these false campaign speech laws, which are found in at least 17 states, pose a constitutional threat to free speech.
lead_paragraph: It started when the Ohio Election Commission received a complaint against a mechanical engineer who, on Twitter, asked voters to stop a streetcar project.

headline.print_headline: Was That Twitter Blast False, or Just Honest Hyperbole?
headline.seo: Honest Hyperbole and Free Speech - Adam Liptak
headline.main: Was That Twitter Blast False, or Just Honest Hyperbole?
